review.title: A Propound Method for the Improvement of Cluster Quality
review.abstract: In this paper Knockout Refinement Algorithm (KRA) is proposed to refine original clusters obtained by applying SOM and K-Means clustering algorithms. KRA Algorithm is based on Contingency Table concepts. Metrics are computed for the Original and Refined Clusters. Quality of Original and Refined Clusters are compared in terms of metrics. The proposed algorithm (KRA) is tested in the educational domain and results show that it generates better quality clusters in terms of improved metric values.

metadata.title: A Propound Method for the Improvement of Cluster Quality

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: In fact, most people are able to understand themselves and what they are doing.

sections.heading: 2. Process Description and Experiments
sections.text: The raw weblog file we used for the experiment contained 5999 web requests, which can be found at http: / / www.vtsns.edu.rs / maja / vtsnsNov16, which include information such as date / time of the request, hit type, page, hostname, referrer, server domain, authenticated user, server manager, page views, size, etc. To prepare the weblog data for the mining process, it must be deleted from irrelevant requests; and converted into a format that can be fed into the clustering algorithm. For pre-processing and creating sessions, a tool called Sawmill (version 7.0), developed by Flower fire Inc., was used. Sawmill calculates session information by tracking the page, date / time and visitor ID for each page view. When a session view is requested, it processes all of these page calls at the time of the request by contributing to each session's initial request.

sections.heading: 3. Proposed Knockout Refinement Algorithm (KRA)
sections.text: Where q is the number of variables equal to 1 for both i and j sessions, r is the number of variables equal to 1 for session i, but equal to 0 for session j, s is the number of variables equal to 0 for session i and j. In this case, the factor t is unimportant and is ignored to calculate the dissimilarity for all sites. s is the number of variables equal to 0 for session i and equal to 1 for session j and t is the number of variables equal to session i and j. sections.heading: 5. CONCLUSION
sections.text: The proposed algorithms tested on the weblog data show that refined clusters lead to improved Davies Bouldin and Dunn's International Index values; external quality metrics such as Precision, Recall and F-Measure have improved for refined clusters compared to the original clusters; the proposed algorithm is scalable and can be coupled with clustering algorithms to address all other weblog data sets. [Note that the performance of clustering algorithms as a data dependent.REFERENCES [1] Arun Prabha K., R.Saranya. Refinement of K-Means Clustering Using Genetic Algorithms Using Genetic Algorithm; Journal of Computer Applications (JCA) ISSN: 0974-1925, Volume IV, Issue 2, 2011.
